FEDERA School  David Stoney Tes Club It  is "esser of Two Evis"  in Presenting Data  S. David Stoney, principal of  Bennett schoo, spoke on the value  and need of Federal aid in education at yesterday"s meeting of the  Exchange Club at the Francis Marion hote.  J. Francis Brenner, of the Junior  Chamber of Commerce, invited the  cooperation of the Exchange Club  in the present war bond saes drive.  After the meeting there was a ceremony marking the erection of a  patriotic Exchange Club poster on  Marion square in front of the hote.  Prefacing his remarks with the  statement that he was not trying to  force approva of Federal aid, but  merey was presenting the facts to  hep Club members reach an inteigent decision, Mr. Stoney said, "It  seems to me that Federal aid is the  esser of two evis".  The speaker first presented two  situations to indicate the pressing  need for more adequate educationa  facilities. One was the acute congestion of schoos in the Charleston  area, due to wartime population increases, and the consequent shift to  double sessions with inevitable deterioration in education. The second was the post-war crisis ikey  to follow within ten years due to  the war strain on word economy.  One More generaltion  "We have, then, about one more  generaltion to train to meet that  crisis. If we don"t do it, what chance  Is there to sove the problems of the  post-war period?" Mr. Stoney asked.  He then showed a series of sides  iustrating South Carolina"s position in educationa facilities and  wealth in comparison with the educationa facilities and wealth of  the rest of the nation.  Among the statistics given, from  which Mr. Stoney eft the audience  to draw its own concusions about  Federal aid, were the following:  South Carolina has 590 children  of ages five to seventeen, for each  1,000 aduts, the highest- ratio in  the nation, and is among the owest  in wealth and income. At the same  time, the states such as New York  which have the owest reative  number of children to educate have  the highest wealth and income figures.  In South Carolina, $32 a year per  chid is the amount spent for education. In New York, the figure  is  $135,  over four times  as  much.  "You are going to get the kind of  program you pay for, and you can"t  get an adequate educationa program for $32," Mr. Stoney commented.  Other figures were presented  tending to indicate that South Carolina cannot from its own wealth  and funds provide fu support for  an adequate educationa program.  The reative taxpaying ability here  was cited as $7; that in other states,  such as Deaware, was isted as six  to seven times that much.  More Taxes Needed  South Carolina already is using  90 per cent of its reative taxpaying abiity, but if 100 per cent, or  a of it, were used, this would  provide only about one-third enough  for a defensibe minimum School  program, Mr. Stoney"s figures indicated. It would take 275 per cent  of the state"s reative taxpaying  ability to support an educationa  program costing only $42 a year per  chid, his tables showed.  ""After citing yeary average  teachers" saaries in New York as  $2,600 a year and in South Carolina  as $743 a year, indicating disproportionate ability to support education in other states, Mr. Stoney  quoted figures for 1928 to 1937 showing South Carolina with the greatest increase for the period of any  state in the nation in the amount  of money taken from the state in  taxes by the Federal government.  The meeting was adjourned to the  site of the Club"s poster across the  street, where the Club president,  Charles H. Webb, Jr., officiated at  the pasting up of the last sheet. The  biboard depicts a fast boat surging forward, guns bazing, as an  incentive to fu speed ahead in the  war effort. The Club"s name is at  the bottom as sponsor of the sign.  Preceding Mr. Stoney"s ecture,  Mr. Brenner discussed the war bond  saes drive, and asked the Club to  name a committee to cooperate with  the Jaycees, particuary in the matter of promoting further use of the  payro deductfbn plan in Charleston  industries.  Sogan  Is  Coined  He quoted Exchangite Harod Petit as the coiner of a sogan, "If  you can"t fight back over there, you  can back fight over here", which  he said would be adopted in the  campaign.  Mr. Webb appointed C. B. Pearce  as chairman and Rov Zeiger, Dr.  W. H. Price and j. wifred D.  Zerbst as members of a committee  to assist in the bond drive.  A letter from Robert T. Stanton,  a former member of the Club, now  in Birmingham, Mich., was read  and the Club secretary, Morrison  eand, was authorized to write for  the Club in repy.  It was announced that the meeting date will be shifted September  9 from Thursday of each week to  Wednesday. A former member, Car  Espy, was present as a guest.   - -

THE NEWS AND COURIE  Education Week Observed  in Negro Schoos  The following artice was prepared by principas of negro  Public schoos of the city system and is pubished as the  final artice in a series on education week.  Throughout the week of November 10-14 the negro Public schoos  have been ceebrating American  Education week through programs  in cassrooms, assembies, pays and  buetin board exhibits. The programs throughout the schoos follow:  ARCHER  The entire program at Archer  during the week was buit around  "The Part Archer Pays in Meeting  the Education Week Theme of Education for a Strong America." This  was carried out through buetin  board exhibits, assembies and  cassroom activities. A special program on Tuesday evening at 8  o clock, at the reguar Farent-   Teacher  Association was presented  following the same theme.  BURKE  At the high School Monday at  9:30 a. m. a round table was held  as an assemby program, presented  by the senior group. The topic  was "Education for a Strong America." On Wednesday at 11:30 the  senior group again presented a  round table discussion, vMuch evoved into a general discussion with  questions and opinions coming from  the audience.  BUIST  At Buist each day a topic was  discussed in each class during a  period set aside for this purpose.  These discussions followed the outine of the national Education as  socialtion as follows: buiding physical fitness, improving economic we  being, safeguarding School support,  earning the way of democracy.  These, topics were reworded when  necessary to meet the level of the  students.  SIMONTON  Education week at Simonton  was ceebrated with an educationa  assemby program Monday, entitled  "The Discovery of America" On  Wednesday at 9 a. m. another program was presented entitled  "American Youth at Pay." Both  programs were presented by students under the supervision of  teachers. Thursday in each class  thefe was a homeroom activity to  touch each student throughout the  schoo.  Friday each School had a guest  speaker at the assemby program.  The speakers were officers of the  army and navy stationed at Fort  Moutrie or at the navy yard. This  arrangement was made from the  superintendent"s office and with the  kindness of H. O. Strohecker, principal of toe Charleston High schoo.  Thursday evening at 8:15 o clock  at the Archer School the Parent-  Teacher associaltions of the four  schoos had a joint meeting at  which time a program was presented with music from the schoo"s  gee Club. President S. R. Hig-  gins of Aen university was the  guest speaker deivering the education address.  -Parents of the students in these  schoos were invited to attend a of  these programs and activities, to  show the parents who their children  are doing in School as we as to  encourage these young people.
